title: Costa Rica’s Escazú Has Beautiful Scenery, a Temperate Climate and Lots of Amenities
text:
Escazú, an upscale suburb 10 minutes from the capital city of San Jose, is the Beverly Hills of Costa Rica.

Its name comes from the indigenous word “Izt-kat-zu,” which means “resting stone.” As legend has it, it was a popular resting spot for those traveling between the villages of Aserri and Pacaca.

Today, with its exclusive shopping malls, fine restaurants and breathtaking mountain views, it’s a popular resting spot for those seeking sophistication as well as chic seclusion.

More: Coconut Grove, a Miami Neighborhood That Feels Like a ‘Small Town With a Big-City Vibe’

Boundaries

Escazú is a canton or subdivision of Costa Rica’s San Jose province that has some 67,000 inhabitants and covers nearly 14 square miles. It’s bounded by the canton of Belen on the north and east, the canton of Santa Ana on the west and the cantons of Mora and Acosta on the south.

The canton of Escazú itself has three districts: San Miguel de Escazú, San Antonio and San Rafael. San Miguel de Escazú, the capital city of the canton, is in the central district. Santa Ana Canton is on its western boundary, the San Rafael district is on the north and east and the San Antonio district is on the south.

Price Range

At the luxury end of the market, prices for single-family houses range from US$500,000 to US$8 million, according to Yalile Alpizar, broker/owner of Costa Rica Luxury. (She added that prices are regularly quoted in U.S. dollars for the international market.)

A US$500,000 house, she said, would be about 300 square meters and would be on a 500-square-meter lot. An US$8 million home, the highest listing in the neighborhood now, is 2,000 square meters and is on a 20,000-square-meter lot.

Alejandra Ibarra, a broker with Costa Rica Sotheby’s International Realty, said that while large private estates start at US$3 million, the typical range for single-family homes is US$500,000 to US$1 million. Such single-family homes, she added, are usually resales, with four to five bedrooms and bathrooms, maid’s quarters and large gathering areas.

More: Beijing’s Shunyi Central Villa District Offers a Suburban Idyll

This 21,572-square-foot home, set on 4.82 acres, is listed for $6.999 million. In addition to seven bedrooms and seven bathrooms, it has a five-car garage, a terrace, an infinity-edge swimming pool, an in-house movie theater and parking for 40 vehicles. Luxury Homes Costa Rica

John Ordonez, CEO at Luxury Homes Costa Rica, noted that the wide range of prices reflects the neighborhood’s mix of income levels. Because of this, he said, “Next to a million-dollar home, you can see a very poor family.”

One-bedroom condos in some of the most sought-after developments, including Central Park, Cerro Alto, Distrito Cuatro, Torre Country, Avenida Escazú, Escazú Village, Hacienda el Poró, Valle del Tamarindo, Monteplata and El Cortijo, start at US$180,000, Ms. Alpizar said. At the top of the market, a 400-square-meter penthouse can reach US$2 million, she added.

Mr. Ordonez said that he’s seen condo prices go even higher—to US$4 million— in the most coveted, luxurious towers.

The difference in condo prices, added Ms. Ibarra, reflects the location, amenities and size of each unit. “The fact that you can buy a new and nice condo for an average of US$400,000 makes it achievable for young professionals with or without family to live here,” she added.

More: Saint-Thomas-d’Aquin, a Picture-Postcard Neighborhood in Paris

Housing Stock

Large estates designed by award-winning local architects dominate the housing market. Typically, they have manicured gardens and swimming pools. Some of the grander ones also feature entertainment spaces, spas, gyms, home theaters, guest houses and caretakers’ cottages.

“Most of the homes offer spectacular panoramic mountain and city views,” Ms. Alpizar said.

There are two styles of architecture: ultra-contemporary and traditional Mediterranean/hacienda-style.

Ms. Alpizar said that “the classic colonial style has taken a second place; there is much more demand for a modern architectural design and the finest finishes.”

More: New Orleans’s Garden District Boasts 19th-Century Charm With 21st-Century Comforts

Mr. Ordonez noted that most of the homes are 25 years old and in gated communities and that they have a variety of amenities, including pools, playgrounds, tennis courts, clubhouses, fitness centers and even movie theaters.

The condos, which are about the same ages as the single-family homes, are in a variety of architectural styles, including Colonial, Art Nouveau, contemporary and modern, according to Ms. Ibarra.

Listed for $1.95 million, this estate has four bedrooms and four bathrooms. Daniela Guillen

What Makes It Unique

Escazú, which is surrounded by green mountains and has permanent spring-like weather, is in a prime location for luxurious living.

Ms. Alpizar noted that the beaches of the Central Pacific Coast are only an hour’s drive away.

“There’s a nice highway that connects the Central Valley with the beaches,” she said. “You can be at the Pacific Ocean in less than an hour and in the Caribbean Sea in about three and a half hours. You literally can watch the sun rise in the Caribbean Sea and the sun set in the Pacific Ocean all in the same day.”

She added that the neighborhood’s pack of amenities‚—schools, restaurants, entertainment centers, shops, country clubs and medical services—make it highly desirable for those who can afford it.

From Penta: The World’s Largest Superyacht Is Built to Help the Ocean

“Escazú is one of the most sought-after locations in San Jose among foreigners due to its new infrastructure, amenities and bilingual schools,” Mr. Ordonez added. “It has beautiful hills and offers amazing views of the city and mountains. I believe people move here because of the weather, and housing is not as expensive as it is in some of the world-class cities in the world.”

The fact that Escazú is close to everything and has everything within its borders for cosmopolitan living makes it special, added Ms. Ibarra.

Sited in the mountains of Escazú, this 7,416-square-foot home on 1.21 acres is listed for $1.75 million. It has five bedrooms and bathrooms. Norberto Zavarce

Amenities

Elegant shopping malls and a variety of fine-dining establishments give Escazú an international feel.

The Multiplaza Mall, which Ms. Ibarra noted is the biggest in the country, carries world-renowned brands like Adidas and Victoria’s Secret and features the Real InterContinental Costa Rica Hotel.

The mall also has a variety of bars and restaurants, including Tintos y Blancos, which, according to Ms. Ibarra, “is the spot to go to for fine wine and live music on the weekends.”

More: Cape Town’s Camps Bay is All About the Ocean Views—and the Beach Lifestyle

Mr. Ordonez said there are a number of family-friendly eateries, including Rostipollos, which is known for its roasted chickens; Los Anonos, a barbecue restaurant that has been in the community since 1960; and La Oveja Negra, which serves traditional Costa Rican dishes like chifrijo—a bowl of rice, beans and crackling pork topped with pico de gallo salsa.

El Mestizo, a gastronomic marketplace close to the Multiplaza, features 18 restaurants under its roof, including Tredlo, which serves Central European and Nordic fare, and Cabo Taco, which, as its name implies, specializes in tacos of all types.

The mixed-use development Avenida Escazú, home of the nation’s first IMAX theater and the country’s first Starbucks, has a variety of shops, including Crate & Barrel and Lollipop Kids Boutique, which sells chic children’s clothing. It also has restaurants, food courts, coffee shops, ice cream shops and delis. From its French bistro L’Ile de France and Chinese restaurant P.F. Chang’s to its Costa Rica Beer Factory der Biergarten, it offers international experiences and cuisine.

Outside of Avenida Escazú, Ms. Ibarra’s neighborhood favorites include the popular breakfast/lunch spot Chez Christophe Restaurant and Bakery, which serves homemade pastries and croissants and gourmet sandwiches. Its patio has murals of French scenery that set the mood.

“The service is great, and it’s worth all the calories,” she said.

For more meaty meals, she dines at La Cascada, which she said is “a very old but wonderful steak restaurant. Going there is a family tradition; it has great service, excellent meat and the best caramelized plantains. And El Novillo Alegre, an Argentinian steak restaurant, has the finest cuts.”

More: Cairo’s Zamalek is A Quieter Neighborhood—But It’s Far From Sleepy

The community, whose nickname is La Ciudad de las Brujas (City of the Witches) is home to several festivals.

At the International Folklore Festival in November, artists from around the world show their works.

“It’s also a great time for families and friends to meet and share quality time while enjoying local food and drinks,” Ms. Alpizar said, adding that another event, the Arts Festival, held in April, typically attracts 100 artists not only from Costa Rica but also from Spain, Peru, Colombia, Argentina and even the United States.

She said the annual ox-cart parade, Dia de los Boyers, is “very famous.” The cultural celebration of Costa Rica, complete with cowboys and cowgirls riding brightly colored carts, is held the second Sunday of March.

The Costa Rica Country Club, which Ms. Ibarra said is the “most high profile in the country,” has a golf course and recreational swimming pools as well as competitive swimming pools.

More: Summerlin: A Scorching High-End Nabe in Las Vegas

For culture, residents head to the capital city of San Jose, which is 20 minutes away by car. The National Museum has collections on natural history, anthropology and archaeology. The Pre-Columbian Gold Museum, which is in a building underneath the Plaza de la Cultura public square, has more than 1,600 gold artifacts that date to 500 AD. The Museo del Jade, which was founded in 1977, has the world’s largest collection of American jade as well as pre-Columbian artifacts.

The community’s natural amenities rival the man-made ones. “Some of the entertainment in Escazú has to do with enjoying its natural beauty by going bicycling up to the mountains, climbing up the Pico Blanco mountain, going trout fishing and riding the rough-terrain vehicles and motocross bikes,” Ms. Alpizar said. “As part of a change in lifestyle, many families enjoy planting their own organic herb gardens and keeping their own vegetable gardens and fruit trees.”

The community is 20 minutes from the country’s largest park, La Sabana Metropolitan Park in downtown San José.

More: Puerto Rico’s Condado Beach in San Juan Offers an Idyllic Caribbean Community

There are several private schools in Escazú.

Blue Valley is a bilingual school with an American curriculum and a strong Spanish program for four academic levels: early learning, elementary, secondary and international baccalaureate. Arandú is a bilingual school that takes students from preschool through high school. Established in 1979, St. Mary, a Catholic school for students in preschool through high school, offers a Portuguese program in addition to ones in English and Spanish.

Mount View offers classes for students in preschool through high school. West College, a K-through-12 school, offers dual high school diplomas from the United States and Costa Rica. Lighthouse International School, for students in preschool through high school, also offers an international baccalaureate program.

More: Georgica Association, the Hamptons’ ‘Special and Exclusive’ Enclave, is Less About Being Seen

Who Lives There

Escazú is a welcoming cosmopolitan neighborhood inhabited by VIPs, including a number of ambassadors.

Executives from Amazon, Intel and Walmart also live in the community.

“Most families of heads of large corporations choose to live here because of all the convenience it offers,” Ms. Alpizar said. “It is a family-oriented little town. Locals enjoy having friends and neighbors from different nationalities, and in any case, Costa Ricans are friendly by nature.”

The U.S., Dutch, British, German, Canadian and South Korean ambassadors have their official residences in the neighborhood, and Ms. Ibarra noted that 16%t of its population is international.

“They come here for all the services it has and the security and location,” she said, adding that the locals see Escazú as a status-symbol neighborhood.

Notable Residents

A variety of well-known people live in Escazú. According to Ms. Alpizar, they include the country’s current president, Carlos Alvarado Quesada, as well as a former one, Miguel Ángel Rodríguez Echeverría. So do artists Gerardo Montoya, famous for the festival masks he makes, and Marijose Terán, whose realistic, textural paintings are renowned for their depiction of lush, draped fabrics, she added.

Mr. Ordonez noted that retired NASA astronaut Franklin Ramón Chang Díaz and Óscar Arias Sánchez, another former president of Costa Rica and a Nobel Peace Prize winner, live in Escazú.

And Ms. Ibarra pointed out that Ramon Mendiola, the CEO of the Costa Rica food and beverage company Florida Ice and Farm, is another notable resident.

More: A Costa Rican Contemporary With a Two-Minute Walk to the Beach

Outlook

Costa Rica is in the grips of a real estate recession, which, according to Mr. Ordonez has led to dramatic drops in prices in the last three to five years.

“Costa Rica is a small country, so depending on the specific area, the drop has been 10% to even 70%,” he said. “In Escazú, the drops are from 10% to 40%, depending on the location.”

He added that the market, which he called unpredictable, is “very affected by the U.S. economy.”

Acknowledging that buyers are in command at the present moment, Ms. Alpizar said that prices throughout the nation are routinely being dropped dramatically.

More: Costa Rica’s Sustainable and Striking ‘Floating House’

“Prices are suffering large discounts at closing,” she said. “The typical discount can be between 5% and 10% of the asking price in properties that have already lowered their price, and if the price of the property is still high for the market, sellers can be surprised with offers of up to 30% to 40% discounts to start a negotiation process.”

She added that because of this, “there’s never been a better time to invest in purchasing a second home, a retirement home or a vacation home in Costa Rica.”

Ms. Ibarra sees the market slowdown as a temporary situation. “In the past year, people who needed to sell have considered and accepted offers below the [asking] prices, but sellers who had no hurry to sell opted to wait,” she said. “Prices on new houses are going up at a 5% rate, and land prices will not go down.”

“It’s always in demand,” she said of real estate in Costa Rica, “and Escazú is by far the place to live because of all of its amenities,” she said.
